question_text: What is the difference between Update(), FixedUpdate(), and LateUpdate()?
option_d: Update(): Called every frame, variable frequency based on frame rate. FixedUpdate(): Called at fixed time intervals (default 0.02s) for physics calculations. LateUpdate(): Called after all Update() methods complete, useful for camera follow scripts.

question_text: What are Unity Coroutines and how do they work?
option_d: Coroutines are special methods that can pause execution using yield statements. They use IEnumerator return type and StartCoroutine() to run. Yield instructions: WaitForSeconds, WaitForFixedUpdate, WaitForEndOfFrame, null (next frame). Useful for timed events, animations, sequences.

question_text: What is the difference between GameObject.SetActive() and Destroy()?
option_d: SetActive(): Enables/disables GameObject and components, preserves in memory, can be reactivated. Destroy(): Removes GameObject/component from scene, frees memory (after current frame). DestroyImmediate(): Immediate removal (editor only). Use SetActive() for pooling, Destroy() for permanent removal.

question_text: What are Unity Layers and their uses?
option_d: Layers categorize GameObjects for selective operations. Uses: Camera culling, Raycasting filtering, Physics collision filtering, Editor organization. 32 layers available (0-31). Set in Inspector or via LayerMask in code. LayerMask for operations: Camera.cullingMask, Physics.Raycast layerMask parameter.

question_text: What are Unity Tags and how to use them?
option_d: Tags are string identifiers for GameObjects. Predefined tags: Untagged, Respawn, Finish, EditorOnly, MainCamera, Player, GameController. Uses: GameObject.FindWithTag(), GameObject.FindGameObjectsWithTag(), collision detection (other.CompareTag()). Better performance than GameObject.Find() by name.

question_text: What is the difference between Transform.position and Transform.localPosition?
option_d: Transform.position: World space position (relative to scene origin). Transform.localPosition: Local space position (relative to parent). If no parent, they're identical. Transform.position = parent.position + parent.rotation * localPosition. Use world for absolute positioning, local for hierarchical positioning.

question_text: What are Unity Prefabs and their advantages?
option_d: Prefabs are reusable GameObject templates. Advantages: Reusability, consistency, centralized editing, instantiation at runtime, nesting, variants. Create: GameObject → Create Empty → drag to Project window. Modify prefab instance: Overrides, Apply to save changes.

question_text: What is the difference between Instantiate() and Resources.Load()?
option_d: Resources.Load(): Loads asset from Resources folder at runtime, returns asset reference. Instantiate(): Creates GameObject instance from prefab or existing GameObject. Typically: Instantiate(Resources.Load<GameObject>('prefab')). Resources.Load for loading, Instantiate for creating instances.

question_text: What are Unity Events and UnityEvent system?
option_d: UnityEvent is serializable delegate system. Allows inspector-based event binding. Benefits: Decoupling, visual editing, no-code connections. Types: UnityEvent (no params), UnityEvent<T0>, etc. Use [Serializable] for custom events. Invoke() triggers event. AddListener() in code.

question_text: What is the difference between OnTriggerEnter() and OnCollisionEnter()?
option_d: OnTriggerEnter(): For trigger colliders (isTrigger=true), no physics interaction, passes through. OnCollisionEnter(): For non-trigger colliders, physics interaction, collision response. Requires at least one Rigidbody (non-kinematic). Use triggers for detection, collisions for physical interactions.

question_text: What are Unity ScriptableObjects and use cases?
option_d: ScriptableObjects are data containers independent of GameObject instances. Use cases: Game settings, item databases, enemy stats, dialogue trees, event systems. Benefits: Memory efficiency (shared data), serialization, inspector editing, asset-based workflow. Create via CreateAssetMenu attribute.

question_text: What is the difference between Awake(), Start(), and OnEnable()?
option_d: Awake(): Called when script instance is loaded (before Start). Start(): Called before first Update if script enabled. OnEnable(): Called whenever GameObject becomes enabled/active. Execution order: Awake (once) → OnEnable (when enabled) → Start (before first Update). Use Awake for initialization, Start for dependency setup.

question_text: What are Unity Raycasts and how to use them?
option_d: Raycast shoots invisible ray to detect collisions. Uses: Line of sight, mouse picking, distance measurement. Methods: Physics.Raycast(), Physics.RaycastAll(), Physics.SphereCast(). Parameters: origin, direction, hitInfo, distance, layerMask. Debug: Debug.DrawRay(). Example: if(Physics.Raycast(transform.position, transform.forward, out hit, 10f))

question_text: What is the difference between Vector3.MoveTowards and Vector3.Lerp?
option_d: Vector3.MoveTowards(): Moves point towards target at constant speed (maxDistanceDelta). Vector3.Lerp(): Linear interpolation between two points by t (0-1). Lerp is percentage-based, MoveTowards is distance-based. SmoothDamp: Smooth acceleration/deceleration. Use MoveTowards for constant speed, Lerp for proportional movement.

question_text: What are Unity Quaternions and Euler angles?
option_d: Euler angles: Three angles (X,Y,Z) in degrees, intuitive but suffers gimbal lock. Quaternion: Four-component (x,y,z,w) complex number, no gimbal lock, efficient interpolation. Transform.rotation uses quaternion, Transform.eulerAngles uses Euler. Convert: Quaternion.Euler(), .eulerAngles. Use quaternions for rotation operations.

question_text: What is the difference between GetComponent() and GetComponentInChildren()?
option_d: GetComponent<T>(): Gets component on current GameObject. GetComponentInChildren<T>(): Gets component on current GameObject or any child (recursive). GetComponentsInChildren<T>(): Gets all matching components. GetComponentInParent<T>(): Gets component on current GameObject or parent. Use specific method for performance vs convenience.

question_text: What are Unity Interfaces and common examples?
option_d: Interfaces define contracts without implementation. Common Unity interfaces: IEnumerator (coroutines), IDamageable (damage system), IInteractable (interaction), IPointerClickHandler (UI events). Benefits: Polymorphism, decoupling, multiple inheritance simulation. Implement with colon: class Player : MonoBehaviour, IDamageable.

question_text: What is the difference between Time.deltaTime and Time.fixedDeltaTime?
option_d: Time.deltaTime: Time since last frame completion (variable). Time.fixedDeltaTime: Fixed timestep for physics (default 0.02s). Use deltaTime in Update() for frame-rate independent movement. Use fixedDeltaTime in FixedUpdate() for physics calculations. Time.timeScale affects both.

question_text: What are Unity Animator States and Parameters?
option_d: Animator States: Animation clips or blend trees in animator controller. Parameters: Variables controlling transitions (Float, Int, Bool, Trigger). Transitions: Rules between states based on parameters. Use SetFloat(), SetBool(), SetTrigger() to control. Layers: Multiple animation layers (base, override).

question_text: What is the difference between Rigidbody.AddForce() and Rigidbody.velocity?
option_d: AddForce(): Applies force considering mass (acceleration). velocity: Directly sets linear velocity (instant). AddForce modes: Force (continuous), Impulse (instant), Acceleration (mass-independent), VelocityChange (mass-independent). Use AddForce for physics-based movement, velocity for direct control (platformers).

question_text: What are Unity Particle Systems main modules?
option_d: Main modules: Main (general settings), Emission (rate), Shape (emitter shape), Velocity, Limit Velocity, Force, Color, Size, Rotation, Collision, Sub Emitters, Texture Sheet Animation, Renderer. Use ParticleSystem component, modify via code or inspector. Play(), Stop(), Pause() methods.

question_text: What is the difference between Camera.ScreenToWorldPoint and Camera.WorldToScreenPoint?
option_d: ScreenToWorldPoint(): Converts screen coordinates (pixels) to world space. WorldToScreenPoint(): Converts world coordinates to screen space. Screen coordinates: (0,0) bottom-left, (Screen.width, Screen.height) top-right. Use for: Mouse interaction, UI positioning relative to world objects, rendering effects.

question_text: What are Unity UI Canvas render modes?
option_d: Canvas render modes: 1. Screen Space - Overlay: Renders on top of everything, scales with screen. 2. Screen Space - Camera: Renders in camera view, can have perspective. 3. World Space: Renders as 3D object in world. Canvas Scaler for resolution independence. Graphic Raycaster for UI interaction.

question_text: What is the difference between Material and Shader?
option_d: Shader: Code/program defining how surface renders (lighting, textures, effects). Material: Instance of shader with specific property values (colors, textures). Materials use shaders. Shader Graph: Visual shader creation. Create materials from shaders, modify properties via Material.SetColor(), SetTexture().

question_text: What are Unity Audio Sources and Audio Listeners?
option_d: Audio Source: Plays audio clips, controls volume, pitch, spatial blend. Audio Listener: Acts as 'ears' in scene (usually on main camera). 3D Sound: Spatial blend > 0, attenuates with distance. Audio Mixer: Advanced audio routing, effects, groups. Use PlayOneShot() for overlapping sounds, Play() for single.

question_text: What is the difference between OnMouseDown() and IPointerClickHandler?
option_d: OnMouseDown(): Built-in MonoBehaviour method, works on any GameObject with Collider. IPointerClickHandler: UI event interface, requires EventSystem and Graphic Raycaster, works on UI elements. Use OnMouseDown() for 3D objects, IPointerClickHandler for UI. For 2D, both work but interfaces preferred for UI.

question_text: What are Unity NavMesh and NavMeshAgent?
option_d: NavMesh: Baked navigation mesh defining walkable areas. NavMeshAgent: Component for AI movement along NavMesh. Methods: SetDestination(), Stop(), Resume(). Properties: speed, acceleration, angularSpeed. Obstacles: NavMeshObstacle for dynamic blocking. Bake in Window → AI → Navigation. Use for enemy AI, NPC movement.

question_text: What is the difference between Transform.Translate() and modifying position directly?
option_d: Transform.Translate(): Moves relative to current position/rotation. Options: Space.Self (local), Space.World. transform.position += Vector3.forward: Direct position modification in world space. Translate() is convenience method, position is direct access. Translate() accounts for rotation when using Space.Self.

question_text: What are Unity AssetBundles and their use cases?
option_d: AssetBundles package assets for dynamic loading. Use cases: DLC, patching, reducing initial download size, platform-specific assets. Process: Build asset bundles, upload to server, download at runtime, load assets. Methods: AssetBundle.LoadFromFile(), LoadAsset<T>(). Manage memory: Unload(false) for assets, Unload(true) for everything.

question_text: What is the difference between Application.dataPath and Application.persistentDataPath?
option_d: Application.dataPath: Read-only path to assets folder (editor) or app data (build). Application.persistentDataPath: Read/write path for saved data (platform-specific). Application.streamingAssetsPath: Read-only for StreamingAssets. Use dataPath for reading resources, persistentDataPath for saving game data.

question_text: What are Unity Light types and properties?
option_d: Light types: Directional (sun/moon), Point (omnidirectional), Spot (cone), Area (soft). Properties: Intensity, Color, Range, Spot Angle, Shadow Type (Hard/Soft). Baked vs Real-time: Baked for static scenes, Real-time for dynamic. Light probes for dynamic objects in baked lighting.

question_text: What is the difference between Static and Dynamic GameObjects?
option_d: Static GameObjects: Marked as static in inspector, don't move at runtime. Benefits: Static batching (draw call reduction), lighting baking, occlusion culling optimization. Dynamic GameObjects: Can move/change at runtime. Use static for environment, dynamic for characters, items.

question_text: What are Unity Quality Settings levels?
option_d: Quality Settings define rendering quality per platform. Levels: Fastest, Fast, Simple, Good, Beautiful, Fantastic. Controls: Texture quality, anti-aliasing, shadow quality, LOD bias, particle count. Set via Application.targetFrameRate, QualitySettings.SetQualityLevel(). Detect device capabilities for automatic quality adjustment.

question_text: What is the difference between OnDestroy() and OnApplicationQuit()?
option_d: OnDestroy(): Called when GameObject is destroyed (scene change, Destroy()). OnApplicationQuit(): Called when application is quitting (editor play mode stop, build exit). Use OnDestroy() for cleanup of GameObject resources, OnApplicationQuit() for application-level cleanup. Both called on MonoBehaviour.

question_text: What are Unity Joint components and types?
option_d: Joint components connect Rigidbodies. Types: Fixed (welded), Hinge (door), Spring (bouncy), Character (ragdoll), Configurable (fully customizable). Properties: Connected Body, Anchor, Axis, Limits. Use for: Physics-based mechanics, ragdolls, vehicles, chains. Configure in inspector or via code.

question_text: What is the difference between MonoBehaviour and ScriptableObject inheritance?
option_d: MonoBehaviour: Attached to GameObjects, has lifecycle methods (Update, Start), scene-based. ScriptableObject: Not attached to GameObjects, data container, asset-based, no lifecycle methods. Use MonoBehaviour for behavior scripts, ScriptableObject for data assets. Both inherit from UnityEngine.Object.

question_text: What are Unity 2D Physics components?
option_d: 2D Physics components: Rigidbody2D, Collider2D (Box, Circle, Polygon, Edge), Joint2D, ConstantForce2D. Differences from 3D: 2D coordinates, separate physics engine, different methods (Physics2D.Raycast). Use for 2D games, sidescrollers, mobile games. Layer collision matrix in Physics2D settings.

question_text: What is the difference between GameObject.Find() and Transform.Find()?
option_d: GameObject.Find(): Searches entire scene by name (slow, use sparingly). Transform.Find(): Searches child GameObjects of transform by name (faster). Better alternatives: Tags, public references, Singletons, dependency injection. GameObject.Find with path: 'Parent/Child'. Transform.Find doesn't search recursively beyond direct children.

question_text: What are Unity Post-processing effects?
option_d: Post-processing effects enhance final image. Common effects: Bloom, Depth of Field, Motion Blur, Color Grading, Vignette, Chromatic Aberration, Film Grain. Use Post-processing Volume (global or local) with Profile. Requires Post-processing package. Configure per camera with Layer Masks.

question_text: What is the difference between Invoke() and Coroutines for delayed execution?
option_d: Invoke(): Schedules method execution after delay. InvokeRepeating(): Repeats method. Coroutines: More flexible with yield statements. Differences: Invoke uses method name string (reflection), Coroutines use IEnumerator. Coroutines can yield different wait types, pause/resume, pass parameters. Prefer Coroutines for complex timing.

question_text: What are Unity Profiler windows and their uses?
option_d: Profiler windows: CPU Usage, Rendering, Memory, Audio, Physics, Network. Uses: Performance bottleneck identification, memory leak detection, optimization guidance. Record gameplay, analyze spikes. Deep Profiler for detailed analysis. Use in editor and development builds.

question_text: What is the difference between SerializeField and public fields?
option_d: SerializeField: Makes private field visible in inspector. public field: Visible in inspector by default. Differences: public allows external class access, SerializeField keeps field private but inspectable. Use [HideInInspector] to hide public fields. Best practice: Use SerializeField for inspector editing with private encapsulation.

question_text: What are Unity Render Pipeline options?
option_d: Render Pipelines: 1. Built-in Render Pipeline (legacy), 2. Universal Render Pipeline (URP) - mobile/VR, 3. High Definition Render Pipeline (HDRP) - AAA graphics. URP: Scalable, forward rendering. HDRP: Physically based, deferred rendering. Choose based on target platform, graphics requirements.

question_text: What is the difference between DontDestroyOnLoad and SceneManager.LoadScene?
option_d: DontDestroyOnLoad(): Prevents GameObject destruction when loading new scene. SceneManager.LoadScene(): Loads new scene, destroys current scene objects (unless DontDestroyOnLoad). Use DontDestroyOnLoad for persistent objects (GameManager, AudioManager). SceneManager loads scenes additively or single.

question_text: What are Unity Input System actions and bindings?
option_d: Input System: New system replacing old Input Manager. Actions: Abstract inputs (Move, Jump). Bindings: Specific controls (WASD, Gamepad stick). Action Maps: Groups of actions (Gameplay, UI). Processors: Modify input (Normalize, Invert). Use InputActionAsset, PlayerInput component. More flexible, supports more devices.

question_text: What is the difference between Collider and Trigger colliders?
option_d: Collider: Physical collision geometry, blocks objects, calls OnCollision events. Trigger collider: Same geometry but isTrigger=true, no physics blocking, calls OnTrigger events. Use colliders for solid objects, triggers for detection zones. Both need Rigidbody for collision detection (except static colliders).

question_text: What are Unity Addressable Assets system?
option_d: Addressable Assets: System for loading assets by address instead of path. Benefits: Simplified asset management, automatic dependency handling, memory management, remote asset loading. Use Addressables.LoadAssetAsync(), InstantiateAsync(). Groups assets for different platforms, DLC.

question_text: What is the difference between Quaternion.LookRotation and Transform.LookAt?
option_d: Quaternion.LookRotation(): Creates rotation looking along forward vector towards target direction. Transform.LookAt(): Rotates transform to look at target position. LookRotation returns quaternion, LookAt directly modifies rotation. Use LookRotation for custom rotation logic, LookAt for simple look-at behavior.

question_text: What are Unity Terrain tools and features?
option_d: Terrain tools: Paint Height, Paint Texture, Place Trees, Paint Details (grass), Terrain Settings. Features: Heightmap editing, layers, splatmaps, tree placement, wind zones, grass rendering. Use for open worlds, landscapes. Terrain component with Terrain Data asset. Optimize with LOD, occlusion culling.

question_text: What is the difference between Array, List, and Dictionary in Unity C#?
option_d: Array: Fixed-size, contiguous memory, fastest access. List<T>: Dynamic array, resizable, convenient methods. Dictionary<TKey,TValue>: Key-value pairs, fast lookup by key. Use Array for fixed data, List for dynamic collections, Dictionary for lookups. Unity serializes arrays and lists (not dictionaries).

question_text: What are Unity Script Execution Order settings?
option_d: Script Execution Order controls order of MonoBehaviour lifecycle methods. Set via Edit → Project Settings → Script Execution Order. Use when: Scripts have dependencies, need specific update order. Default order is arbitrary. Negative numbers execute earlier. Affects Awake(), Start(), Update(), FixedUpdate().

question_text: What is the difference between Forward and Deferred rendering?
option_d: Forward Rendering: Calculates lighting per object, good for transparency, limited lights. Deferred Rendering: Renders geometry first, then lighting in screen space, supports many lights, no transparency. URP uses forward, HDRP uses deferred. Choose based on lighting complexity, platform.

question_text: What are Unity Timeline and Playable Director?
option_d: Timeline: Non-linear animation/sequence editor. Playable Director: Component that plays Timeline assets. Tracks: Animation, Activation, Audio, Control (sub-timelines). Use for cutscenes, cinematic sequences, complex animations. Control via code: Play(), Stop(), Pause(), Evaluate(time).

question_text: What is the difference between OnValidate() and Reset() in editor scripts?
option_d: OnValidate(): Called when script is loaded or inspector values change (editor only). Reset(): Called when component is reset via context menu (editor only). Use OnValidate() for validation, updating references. Use Reset() for setting default values. Both execute in editor, not in builds.

question_text: What are Unity Occlusion Culling techniques?
option_d: Occlusion Culling: Hides objects not visible to camera. Techniques: 1. Baking occlusion data (static), 2. Portal culling (manual), 3. Dynamic occlusion via bounds. Use Occlusion Culling window, bake data. Requires static objects marked occluder/occludee. Reduces draw calls for indoor/complex scenes.

question_text: What is the difference between MonoBehaviour and Component?
option_d: Component: Base class for everything attached to GameObjects. MonoBehaviour: Derived from Component, adds Unity message system (Update, Start). All MonoBehaviours are Components, not all Components are MonoBehaviours (Transform, Collider are Components but not MonoBehaviours).

question_text: What are Unity Shader Graph nodes and master nodes?
option_d: Shader Graph nodes: Mathematical operations, textures, UV manipulation, lighting. Master nodes: Final output definitions (PBR, Unlit, Sprite Lit). Create visual shaders without code. Properties exposed to Material inspector. Sub-graphs for reusable components. Use for custom effects, stylized rendering.

question_text: What is the difference between Build Settings and Player Settings?
option_d: Build Settings: Scene order, target platform, development build options. Player Settings: Company name, product name, icon, splash screen, resolution, scripting backend, API compatibility level. Configure both before building. Build Settings for build-specific, Player Settings for app-wide.

question_text: What are Unity Physics Materials and their properties?
option_d: Physics Material defines collision behavior. Properties: Dynamic Friction, Static Friction, Bounciness, Friction Combine, Bounce Combine. Physics Material 2D for 2D physics. Use for: Ice (low friction), rubber (high bounciness), different surface interactions. Attach to colliders.

question_text: What is the difference between async/await and Coroutines?
option_d: async/await: C# language feature for asynchronous operations. Coroutines: Unity-specific yield-based system. Differences: async uses Task, Coroutines use IEnumerator. async better for I/O operations, web requests. Coroutines better for frame-based timing, Unity integration. Both can run concurrently.

question_text: What are Unity VR/XR Interaction Toolkit components?
option_d: XR Interaction Toolkit: Framework for VR/AR interactions. Components: XR Rig (player), XR Controller (input), XR Interactable (interactable objects), XR Ray Interactor (pointing). Use for: Grab, throw, teleport, UI interaction in VR. Supports Oculus, SteamVR, OpenXR. Event-based interaction system.

question_text: What is the difference between Gizmos and Handles in Unity editor?
option_d: Gizmos: Simple 3D visuals in Scene view (runtime & editor). Handles: Interactive editor tools for manipulating objects (editor only). Gizmos: DrawWireSphere, DrawLine. Handles: PositionHandle, RotationHandle, ScaleHandle. Use Gizmos for debugging, Handles for custom editor tools.

question_text: What are Unity Burst Compiler and Job System?
option_d: Burst Compiler: Compiles C# to highly optimized native code. Job System: Multithreading system for parallel processing. Use for: Physics, animations, large data processing. Requirements: Unity Mathematics, Burst compatible code (no managed references). Significantly improves performance for CPU-intensive tasks.

question_text: What is the difference between Local and Global space in Unity?
option_d: Local Space: Relative to parent transform (or object itself if no parent). Global/World Space: Relative to scene origin. Transform methods accept Space parameter: Space.Self (local), Space.World (global). Use local for hierarchical objects, global for absolute positioning. TransformPoint() converts between spaces.

question_text: What are Unity Animation Curves and their uses?
option_d: Animation Curves: Define how value changes over time (keyframes with tangents). Uses: Smooth movement, easing, custom animation timing, procedural animation. Edit in inspector or Animation window. Use in code: curve.Evaluate(time). Create via AnimationCurve class. Useful for non-linear interpolation.

question_text: What is the difference between OnGUI() and new UI System?
option_d: OnGUI(): Legacy Immediate Mode GUI (IMGUI), code-based, no GameObjects, good for editor tools, poor performance for runtime UI. New UI System: GameObject-based (Canvas, RectTransform), component-based, better performance, visual editing, supports animations, responsive design. Use new UI for games, OnGUI for editor extensions.

question_text: What are Unity Mesh components and Mesh Filter/Renderer?
option_d: Mesh: Vertex data defining 3D shape. Mesh Filter: Holds mesh reference. Mesh Renderer: Renders mesh with materials. Skinned Mesh Renderer: For animated meshes (bones). Modify meshes at runtime via Mesh class (vertices, triangles, UVs). Use for procedural geometry, mesh deformation.

question_text: What is the difference between PlayMode and EditMode tests?
option_d: PlayMode Tests: Run in Play Mode, test runtime behavior, can use GameObjects. EditMode Tests: Run in Edit Mode, test editor scripts, faster. Unity Test Framework supports both. Use PlayMode for gameplay testing, EditMode for utility/editor testing. Create via Test Runner window.

question_text: What are Unity Package Manager and custom packages?
option_d: Package Manager: Install, remove, update Unity packages. Packages: Official (UI, 2D, XR) and custom. Custom packages: Share code/assets between projects, version control. Create via Create → Assembly Definition, then export as .tgz. Use for: Reusable systems, team libraries, asset store submissions.

question_text: What is the difference between Box Collider and Mesh Collider?
option_d: Box Collider: Simple rectangular collider, low performance cost, approximate shape. Mesh Collider: Uses mesh geometry for accurate collision, higher performance cost, can be convex (simplified) or non-convex (exact). Use Box for simple shapes, Mesh for complex accuracy. Mesh Collider can be heavy for runtime.

question_text: What are Unity Sprite Renderer properties?
option_d: Sprite Renderer properties: Sprite (image), Color (tint), Material, Sorting Layer, Order in Layer, Mask Interaction, Sprite Draw Mode (Simple, Sliced, Tiled). Use for 2D graphics, UI elements, particle sprites. Sprite Atlas for batching. Sprite Editor for slicing, animations.

question_text: What is the difference between Resources.Load and AssetDatabase.LoadAssetAtPath?
option_d: Resources.Load(): Runtime loading from Resources folder. AssetDatabase.LoadAssetAtPath(): Editor-only loading from any project path. Use Resources for runtime, AssetDatabase for editor scripts/tools. Resources has build size impact (includes all Resources). AssetDatabase requires using UnityEditor namespace.

question_text: What are Unity Cinemachine virtual cameras?
option_d: Cinemachine: Camera system for complex camera behaviors. Virtual Cameras: Camera profiles with behaviors (Follow, Look At, Noise, Impulse). Brain: Blends between virtual cameras. Extensions: Confiner (boundaries), Collider (obstacle avoidance). Use for: Cutscenes, player follow, multi-camera setups.

question_text: What is the difference between Rigidbody.interpolation and extrapolation?
option_d: Interpolation: Smooths movement between physics updates (FixedUpdate). Options: None, Interpolate, Extrapolate. Interpolate uses previous frame, Extrapolate predicts next frame. Use for smooth camera following rigidbody. Interpolation adds 1 frame latency. Configure on Rigidbody component.

question_text: What are Unity Particle System emission over time vs distance?
option_d: Emission over Time: Constant particle emission (rate over time). Emission over Distance: Emits particles when emitter moves (rate over distance). Bursts: Sudden particle bursts. Use time for continuous effects (fire, smoke), distance for trail effects, bursts for explosions. Configure in Emission module.

question_text: What is the difference between Application.Quit() and SceneManager.LoadScene()?
option_d: Application.Quit(): Exits application (ignored in editor, works in build). SceneManager.LoadScene(): Loads new scene, continues application. Use Quit() for exit button, LoadScene() for level transitions. On WebGL, Quit() may not work (browser restriction). Check Application.isEditor for platform-specific behavior.

question_text: What are Unity Line Renderer and Trail Renderer components?
option_d: Line Renderer: Draws lines between points in 3D space. Trail Renderer: Leaves trail behind moving object. Use for: Laser beams, drawing tools, motion trails, weapon effects. Configure: Width, Color gradient, Materials, Positions. Update positions at runtime for dynamic effects.

question_text: What is the difference between MonoBehaviour and plain C# class?
option_d: MonoBehaviour: Unity-specific, attached to GameObjects, has lifecycle methods, serializable fields, works with Unity editor. Plain C# class: Standard C#, no Unity integration, no lifecycle, can't attach to GameObjects. Use MonoBehaviour for game behavior, plain classes for data/logic without Unity dependencies.

question_text: What are Unity Asset Import Settings for textures?
option_d: Texture Import Settings: Texture Type (Default, Normal Map, Sprite), Wrap Mode, Filter Mode, Compression, Max Size, Generate Mip Maps, sRGB. Configure per platform (Override for Android/iOS). Use for: Optimization, quality control, memory management. Apply via Import Settings window.

question_text: What is the difference between yield return null and yield return WaitForEndOfFrame?
option_d: yield return null: Waits until next frame (after Update). yield return WaitForEndOfFrame: Waits until after all cameras and GUI rendered. Use null for frame delay, WaitForEndOfFrame for capturing screenshots, post-render operations. WaitForFixedUpdate: Waits until next FixedUpdate.

question_text: What are Unity UI Layout components?
option_d: Layout components: Vertical/Horizontal Layout Group (arranges children), Content Size Fitter (sizes to content), Layout Element (override sizes), Grid Layout Group (grid arrangement). Use for responsive UI, dynamic content. Combined with Canvas Scaler for resolution independence.

question_text: What is the difference between Physics.SphereCast and Physics.OverlapSphere?
option_d: Physics.SphereCast: Casts sphere along direction, returns first hit (like thick raycast). Physics.OverlapSphere: Returns all colliders within sphere at position. Use SphereCast for movement prediction (character controller), OverlapSphere for area detection (explosion radius). Both use layer masks for filtering.

question_text: What are Unity 2D Tilemap system components?
option_d: Tilemap system: Tilemap (grid for tiles), Tilemap Renderer, Tilemap Collider 2D, Grid (parent component). Tile assets: Rule Tiles (auto-tiling), Animated Tiles. Use for: 2D levels, platformers, strategy games. Edit with Tile Palette window. Optimize with Chunk caching.

question_text: What is the difference between EditorWindow and Editor class?
option_d: EditorWindow: Creates standalone editor windows (like Scene, Game windows). Editor: Custom inspector for components (extends UnityEditor.Editor). Use EditorWindow for tools, utilities. Use Editor for custom component inspectors. Both require using UnityEditor namespace, don't work in builds.

question_text: What are Unity ProBuilder modeling tools?
option_d: ProBuilder: In-editor 3D modeling tools. Features: Create/edit meshes, UV editing, vertex/edge/face manipulation, texture application. Use for: Level prototyping, simple models, blocking out scenes. Integrated in Unity, no external modeling software needed. Export as prefabs or meshes.

question_text: What is the difference between Application.targetFrameRate vs VSync?
option_d: Application.targetFrameRate: Sets maximum frame rate (0 = unlimited). VSync: Synchronizes frame rate with monitor refresh rate (QualitySettings.vSyncCount). VSync prevents screen tearing but can limit FPS. Use targetFrameRate for consistent gameplay, VSync for visual quality. On mobile, targetFrameRate saves battery.

question_text: What are Unity Material Property Blocks?
option_d: MaterialPropertyBlock: Modify material properties without creating new material instance. Benefits: Batch rendering optimization, avoid material instances. Use for: Large numbers of objects with small variations (color, texture offset). Set properties, apply to Renderer.SetPropertyBlock().

question_text: What is the difference between Debug.Log and Debug.DrawRay?
option_d: Debug.Log(): Outputs text to Console window. Debug.DrawRay(): Draws ray in Scene view for specified duration. Debug.DrawLine(): Draws line between points. Use Log for information, DrawRay/DrawLine for visual debugging of vectors, directions, raycasts. Only visible in editor, not in builds.

question_text: What are Unity WebGL build considerations?
option_d: WebGL considerations: Memory limits, no threads (use Web Workers), file system access restrictions, download size matters, browser compatibility. Use: Application.ExternalEval() for JavaScript interaction, WebGL compression, AssetBundles for streaming. Test in multiple browsers.

question_text: What is the difference between OnApplicationPause and OnApplicationFocus?
option_d: OnApplicationPause(): Called when app pauses/resumes (mobile background, alt-tab). OnApplicationFocus(): Called when app gains/loses focus (window focus). On mobile, both called but order varies. Use for: Saving game on pause, pausing gameplay, handling interruptions. Check Application.isFocused, Application.isPlaying.

question_text: What are Unity Custom Editors and Property Drawers?
option_d: Custom Editor: Override inspector for specific component type. Property Drawer: Custom drawer for specific property/attribute. Use [CustomEditor(typeof(MyClass))], [CustomPropertyDrawer(typeof(MyAttribute))]. Create custom inspectors, specialized property editing. Only works in Unity editor.

question_text: What is the difference between Texture2D and Sprite?
option_d: Texture2D: Raw image data, used for 3D textures, materials, render textures. Sprite: 2D graphic object with additional metadata (pivot, borders, slicing). Sprites use Texture2D as source. Use Texture2D for 3D/procedural textures, Sprites for 2D graphics. Convert: Sprite.Create(texture, rect, pivot).

question_text: What are Unity Assembly Definition files?
option_d: Assembly Definition (.asmdef): Defines C# assembly for code organization. Benefits: Controlled dependencies, faster compilation, namespaces. References: Other assemblies, Unity assemblies. Use for: Modular code structure, separating editor/runtime code, package development. Apply to folders, affects compilation.

question_text: What is the difference between Physics.Raycast and Physics2D.Raycast?
option_d: Physics.Raycast(): 3D raycast, uses Vector3, RaycastHit. Physics2D.Raycast(): 2D raycast, uses Vector2, RaycastHit2D. Different coordinate systems, separate physics engines. Use 3D for 3D games, 2D for 2D games. Parameters similar but types differ. Both support layer masks, distance.

question_text: What are Unity Video Player component features?
option_d: Video Player: Plays video files in game. Features: Playback control (play, pause, stop), audio track support, render targets (Camera, RenderTexture, Material), looping, playback speed. Supported formats: MP4, MOV, WebM. Use for: Cutscenes, tutorials, background videos.

question_text: What is the difference between MonoBehaviour and Behaviour?
option_d: Behaviour: Base class for components that can be enabled/disabled. MonoBehaviour: Derived from Behaviour, adds Unity message system. Behaviour has .enabled property, MonoBehaviour inherits it. Collider, Renderer are Behaviours but not MonoBehaviours. All MonoBehaviours are Behaviours.

question_text: What are Unity Gradient and Color properties?
option_d: Gradient: Smooth transition between colors. Use for: Particle colors, UI effects, terrain painting, skyboxes. Gradient Editor in inspector. Gradient.Evaluate(time) for sampling. Color: RGBA values, Color.Lerp() for interpolation, ColorUtility.TryParseHtmlString() for hex colors. Color spaces: Gamma (legacy), Linear (PBR).

question_text: What is the difference between PlayerPrefs and serialization for save data?
option_d: PlayerPrefs: Simple key-value store for small data (int, float, string). Serialization: Custom binary/JSON/XML save system for complex data. PlayerPrefs limitations: Size limits, platform differences, insecure. Serialization benefits: Complex structures, encryption, compression. Use PlayerPrefs for settings, serialization for game saves.

question_text: What are Unity Editor Scripting attributes?
option_d: Editor attributes: [MenuItem] (menu items), [ContextMenu] (component context), [Header], [Tooltip], [Range], [Space], [TextArea], [HideInInspector], [ExecuteInEditMode], [DisallowMultipleComponent], [RequireComponent]. Use to enhance inspector, add editor functionality.

question_text: What is the difference between Transform.rotation and Transform.localRotation?
option_d: Transform.rotation: World space rotation (quaternion). Transform.localRotation: Local space rotation relative to parent. Transform.eulerAngles / localEulerAngles for Euler angles. Use world for absolute orientation, local for hierarchical rotation. Modify via Quaternion methods (Multiply, Slerp, LookRotation).

question_text: What are Unity Compute Shader basics?
option_d: Compute Shader: GPU programming for general-purpose computation. Use for: Particle systems, physics, image processing, AI. Structure: Kernels, buffers, threads. Dispatch kernels from C#. Benefits: Massive parallelism, GPU speed. Limitations: Platform support, complexity. Use ComputeBuffer for data transfer.

question_text: What is the difference between DOTS and traditional Unity?
option_d: DOTS (Data-Oriented Technology Stack): New architecture emphasizing performance. Components: ECS (Entities, Components, Systems), C# Job System, Burst Compiler. Traditional: GameObject/MonoBehaviour OOP approach. DOTS benefits: Performance, cache efficiency, parallelism. Use for: High-performance games, simulations, large entity counts.
